statement: University administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest and free speech, but they also have a duty to maintain order, safety, and respect for all, regardless of background or beliefs. I think they should set clear, consistently enforced rules that prevent harassment, vandalism, and disruptions to classes, while still allowing students to express strong, even unpopular, opinions. Universities shouldn’t take sides politically, but they should encourage civil dialogue, fact-based discussion, and opportunities for people to actually listen to each other instead of just shouting past one another.

Students can and should express their views on Israel and Gaza, but once protests block buildings, threaten others, or turn hateful, the administration must step in firmly, apply discipline fairly, and, if necessary, involve law enforcement. From my perspective, universities are places for learning, not chaos, and leaders should show backbone instead of bending to loudest voices.

statement: University administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, even when the views are unpopular, as long as no one is being harassed or threatened. Coming from a working-class background, I see college as one of the few spaces where people should be pushed to confront hard truths about power, colonialism, and human rights, not shielded from them. At the same time, they need clear, consistently enforced rules that keep everyone physically safe and prevent doxxing, hate speech, or targeting people based on their identity or religion. The goal should be to create space for strong, even uncomfortable political expression while still upholding basic dignity and safety for all students.

The job of the university is to protect safety and order first, and then make sure both sides can speak without fear.

statement: As someone who’s lived through many conflicts and seen the cost of dehumanizing “the other,” I believe university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest while drawing a firm line at harassment, threats, and discrimination of any kind. They should create clear, consistently enforced guidelines that allow passionate advocacy for Palestinians and Israelis alike, while also investing in facilitated dialogues, teach-ins, and mental health support so students can process grief and anger constructively rather than turning on one another.

statement: I think campus administrators should let students protest about Israel and Gaza as long as it stays peaceful and nobody is threatened or harassed. People should be allowed to express their beliefs, but the school also has to make sure everyone feels safe going to class, no matter what side they’re on or where they’re from.
